posts.cooked:
Pictured above is a fairly generic four-bar intake I made for the recent CADathon. I’m looking for people’s thoughts on the deployment method.

The intake works on a “spring+gravity-down, winch up” principle for deployment and retraction, with surgical tubing (routing in orange) pulling downwards and a winch (routing in pink) pulling upwards to achieve the blue movement to the position outlined in the green sketch. The winch is driven by a falcon on a 4:1 sport gearbox.

My theory is that this would provide the resilience benefits of piston-based actuation without requiring a compressor and air tanks.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Good work!

Ropes/ strings are a great way to isolate a gearbox (2767 in 2022 did this for the deployable intake). But 4:1 seems quite aggressive, even with a small spool, it will probally be difficult to control (non linear and could turn the intake into a pretzel). High powered servos (you may need to play with horn designs) could be a good option too, since they are isolated via the string

Other notes :

when deployed it looks like the top links are close to over centering, you will likely want a hard stop to prevent this.

A string outside the bumper is a catching hazard, especially if slack, use caution.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
What’s the plan to keep this up before the match? Rely on brake mode/the friction of the system? I’m not experienced with this type of mechanism but it seems like you might have to carefully calibrate the surgical tubing which could be annoying.

Edit: Really cool idea by the way.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
There are lots of great work arounds to this including velcro attached to the intake rollers. Run the intake, rips the velcro off.

Good looking out though!

Watch out for placing holes in polycarb parts, they create stress risers which can lead to brittle fracture. Making the front plate aluminum can end to being stronger due to avoiding the nasty stress risers on plastic without significantly effecting the compliance from side hits.

TheSnowHatHero:

My theory is that this would provide the resilience benefits of piston-based actuation without requiring a compressor and air tanks.

Many intakes have not just springiness, but also damping which helps dissipate energy from impacts preventing damage resulting from high speeds of an otherwise undamped system. Air systems do this because air is forced through restrictive passages in the solenoids, while motor mechanism, with the proper controls tuning, achieve damping by feeding the motor’s own backemf against the motion. For this system, you will likely want some extra damping not just for impacts, but to reduce oscillations from occurring when the robot accelerates.

Skyehawk:

Good work!

Thanks!

Skyehawk:

But 4:1 seems quite aggressive, even with a small spool, it will probally be difficult to control (non linear and could turn the intake into a pretzel).

Here were my calculations. I modeled it as linear with a weight equal to the intake weight plus the spring weight [1], and travel distance measured from CAD. The resistance force should never get even close to this - the spring acts mostly at the top, and the weight mostly at the bottom. I felt fine modeling it as linear because one decreases while the other increases, peaking at opposite ends; would you stray away from that for control purposes?

What do you mean by “turn the intake into a pretzel?”

Skyehawk:

when deployed it looks like the top links are close to over centering, you will likely want a hard stop to prevent this.

Theory was the bumper, but I can see the issue. I’ll edit it in.

Skyehawk:

There are lots of great work arounds to this including velcro atrached to the intake rollers. Run the intake, rips the velcro off.

This is super clever.

Thanks for the feedback, @Skyehawk !

Alex_Y:

Watch out for placing holes in polycarb parts, they create stress risers which can lead to brittle fracture. Making the front plate aluminum can end to being stronger due to avoiding the nasty stress risers on plastic without significantly effecting the compliance from side hits.

Yeah, that tracks. We didn’t have issues last year, but if I think back a little we might’ve with the '22 bot in the offseason. An aluminum plate sounds great - would you recommend pocketing/through-lightening it? We have machine time to spare.

Alex_Y:

Many intakes have not just springiness, but also damping which helps dissipate energy from impacts preventing damage resulting from high speeds of an otherwise undamped system. Air systems do this because air is forced through restrictive passages in the solenoids, while motor mechanism, with the proper controls tuning, achieve damping by feeding the motor’s own backemf against the motion. For this system, you will likely want some extra damping not just for impacts, but to reduce oscillations from occurring when the robot accelerates.

What kind of setup would you use to add dampening to a system like this? I don’t think I’ve seen anything that would do that before.

Thanks for the feedback @Alex_Y !

TheSnowHatHero:

Yeah, that tracks. We didn’t have issues last year, but if I think back a little we might’ve with the '22 bot in the offseason. An aluminum plate sounds great - would you recommend pocketing/through-lightening it? We have machine time to spare.

No. Your intake is not the place to save grams, you want .25 plate to be solid so that its pretty much indestructible (with the other arms being polycarb preventing bending loads)

TheSnowHatHero:

What kind of setup would you use to add dampening to a system like this? I don’t think I’ve seen anything that would do that before

Some gas shocks have damping to them for similar reasons to pneumatic pistons, but you have to make sure to find some that do not use hydraulic fluids as a damping medium. Thee also have the benefit of being pretty close to constant force which both prevents oscillation due to low spring force at the setpoint and violent deployments due to extra high spring tension when retracted.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
TheSnowHatHero:

felt fine modeling it as linear because one decreases while the other increases, peaking at opposite ends; would you stray away from that for control purposes?

It’s not the weight of the mechanism, it is operating on a path that is not linear from a spooling-the-string-in perspective, where pulling too far in causes damage. Pulling the string 1 inch when fully deployed results in an Angular change of \theta whereas pulling the string at the top results in an angular change of \theta`

Now, you may stall the motor first, so the nonlineaity may not be an issue.

Skyehawk:

It’s not the weight of the mechanism, it is operating on a path that is not linear from a spooling-the-string-in perspective, where pulling too far in causes damage. Pulling the string 1 inch when fully deployed results in an Angular change of \thetaθ\theta whereas pulling the string at the top results in an angular change of \theta`θ‘

Actually, its both. Four-bar linkages are also highly non-linear. You probably don’t want to move the intake fast for the non-linearity to be annoying, but most linkages are inherently highly non-linear and something to be aware of.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
(Not the weight of the mechanism that worries me)

Small correction.

Falcon is massive overkill in this situation too, a brushed 550 would likely be fine if targeting a half second (ik op said quarter), and you don’t need to be fully retracted for the intake to be “mostly” safe. A bag is another good option if you had a supply of them, you may even get away with a pair of PLG motors.

The non linearly is something that can be accounted for mechanically (canceling it out) if you really wanted to add the complexity. Otherwise it can REALLY be used to you advantage, i.e. accelerating a mass, self locking, or providing extremely granular control at some places on the path.

posts.name: Jacob Frye
posts.cooked:
A few thoughts:

The spring-retraction only works when the reaction to a force (like ramming a wall) geometrically results in retraction. I believe you have this set up correctly, but it’s close. The base requirement would be to have the lower 4-bar joint (green line) below the point of first contact (red line), being the outer-most wheel. This looks good now, but any lowering of the lower pivot joint would reduce the possibility of weird bending reversing this state. image 900×855 133 KB

The spring-retraction only works when the reaction to a force (like ramming a wall) geometrically results in retraction. I believe you have this set up correctly, but it’s close. The base requirement would be to have the lower 4-bar joint (green line) below the point of first contact (red line), being the outer-most wheel. This looks good now, but any lowering of the lower pivot joint would reduce the possibility of weird bending reversing this state. image 900×855 133 KB

image 900×855 133 KB

image 900×855 133 KB

It looks like you are using the bumper as a hard stop, this is a mistake we repeatedly make. It works when your bumpers are perfect, and then lowers when they sag. I would add an additional hard stop. Additionally, if the intake lowers any further than you have it in your screenshot, it will go into an unrecoverable state (in red): image 900×855 105 KB

It looks like you are using the bumper as a hard stop, this is a mistake we repeatedly make. It works when your bumpers are perfect, and then lowers when they sag. I would add an additional hard stop. Additionally, if the intake lowers any further than you have it in your screenshot, it will go into an unrecoverable state (in red): image 900×855 105 KB

image 900×855 105 KB

image 900×855 105 KB

If you want to avoid the string altogether, you could use a cam pushing on one of the 4-bar plates, might be a little more robust, and would be able to move quite quickly. You might want to apply the force on both sides with an axle all the way across though. image 900×855 103 KB

If you want to avoid the string altogether, you could use a cam pushing on one of the 4-bar plates, might be a little more robust, and would be able to move quite quickly. You might want to apply the force on both sides with an axle all the way across though. image 900×855 103 KB

image 900×855 103 KB

image 900×855 103 KB

The balls can almost find their way out of the intake… just be careful with wheels, non-grippy wheels (like mecanums) might let them slip out, especially when squished against the bumpers. Some poly-belt might help here too image 900×855 102 KB

The balls can almost find their way out of the intake… just be careful with wheels, non-grippy wheels (like mecanums) might let them slip out, especially when squished against the bumpers. Some poly-belt might help here too image 900×855 102 KB

image 900×855 102 KB

image 900×855 102 KB

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: If your linkage can handle it, moving the bottom pivot down would make “freshman run it into a wall” cause the intake to retract: a VERY good feature!

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
To piggyback on this, if geometry dictates an overcentered lower pivot is necessary, you really need to think about how you pass loads into the frame…

The center pivot with the sprocket/arm is a 3/4 inch bushing riding on an aluminum standoff that is supported by 1/4 aluminum plate on the outside and a .100 steel bracket on the inside.

Only failure was shearing 6 8-32 bolts between the sprocket and the steel arm. Adam designed that thing super overkill. Extra arms, bushings, sprockets and standoffs are still in our spare parts tote. Unused.
